The spirits come and go unseen, delivering tens of thousands in bronze as tribute. How unbearable the fraud of carving wood to forge documents—all to spare the ancient camphor at the cost of a life. The pines, revived by cinnabar, might as well carry Lü Dongbin’s ink basket. The lychee trees, preserved by the old woman, still bear the sword marks of Huang Chao.

Here, I humbly encounter one whose heroic standards tower over the ravines, whose steadfast strength upholds the heavens. The hall’s beams await the right timber; the mountain town’s zithers seek the aura of treasure. Firewood is sold in the market, dust gathers in the cooking pot—never mingling with the common folk. The great wind howls, battering the heavy gates; how can the masses be made to see?

Thus, I sought a mighty *jia* tree, erecting it in lofty splendor, renewing the spectacle for ten thousand eyes—how could I begrudge the expense of a thousand gold? The walls of this pavilion may serve for offerings, for none escape the vigilance of Huang Ba’s spirit. My son, like a tiger, has perished—he will not falter in the might of Mount Tai. The peach trees, though planted, remain untouched; the cassia, though hewn, bears no scar.

If not for one who tends the household, who would bestow such blessings? Certain vines and creepers stir in dreams, their roots knowing their origin. I think of the Duke of Shao beneath the sweet pear’s shade—how dare I forget his legacy of uncut grace? Beneath the withered tree, a Daoist is painted; deep roots may yet secure long life.

I, a humble clerk, dined at the governor’s table, returning home late. Forced to preside over banquets, how could I endure the burden? Holding the prefectural decree, I sensed the approach of duty; stepping into the courtyard, I offered my thanks.

I have heard that mountains and rivers gain weight by the people who dwell there, that bells and drums rise and fall with the times. Behold Zhang and Ge’s twin altars, recorded as blessed lands of the realm; Chen and Huang, two scholars, ranked among the Daoist officials of the Zhenghe era. Predecessors and successors alike led with virtue, their inner and outer designs complete.

Yet how the present age diverges from those of old! The wickedness of the stubborn and foolish floods the heavens; the wind of purity and stillness is swept away. Autumn fields yield no grain, leaving the midday steamer to gather dust. Daoist hats and alms bowls fill the air, yet officials gape like fledglings awaiting food. Though plows and hoes receive rain, farmers must beg for grain to sustain their work. Granary taxes remain half-unpaid, while county levies are collected in advance. Debts pile like mountains, deep-rooted corruption festers. Only those of keen insight and resolve can manage the searing trials above and below.

As for me—my nature is meager, my learning unremarkable. I wandered aimlessly in the four directions, occasionally keeping company with elders. Leaning on my staff, I explored the caves of Guilin; pushing aside the reeds, I read the stele by the Wu River. In the eighth month, I watched the tide, often leaning on the riverside tower. At midnight, I drafted dispatches against the northern foe. I visited the shrine of the Sea God at Hailing, drank at the tomb of the Banished Immortal at Caishi. Riding a donkey, I sought the old man Zhao; summoning cranes, I paid homage to West Mountain. Ascending the clear waters of the Yu, I climbed the solitary peak; scaling Red City, I gazed upon the cypress and cedar. My boat drifted on Mirror Lake’s moonlit waves; my cup floated on the winding stream’s current.

Lying in bed, I reflected on my life—my tracks have circled the realm. Returning to my old retreat, my hut now stands at the clouds’ edge. Official documents fill the shelves; elixir herbs line the walls. Content to grow old here, I seek nothing more.

I know that cassia halls and bamboo palaces stand tall near the imperial city, that stone altars and flowered courtyards dot the land of robes and sashes. Since heaven harbors no foolish immortals, why should the world tolerate babbling fools? They value rank; I value righteousness. All are drunk; I alone am sober.

Then came the summons—my name drawn from the register, submitted to the authorities. The brush’s dot marked my fate, consigning me to my homeland. Though I craved the honor of a discerning gaze, I broke the vow of a humble life. Scarcely had the first drops of time passed before I was bound to service, often sighing as I tended to my wounds. My learning is insufficient—how can I uphold the standards of civility? My abilities are dull—surely I will fail in both public and private duties. Not only will I shame the chrysanthemum sacrifices, but I will also stain the peach and plum.

Here, I humbly encounter one whose name ranks high among the imperial scholars, whose position graces the purple halls. As vice-prefect, you govern the wilds, your might subduing the foxes and hares of a thousand villages. As magistrate of Xiao and Zhu, your transformative influence tames the fish and swine of three districts. You shatter the heads of demons with a mere clerk’s mark; the female drought-demon falls victim to a year of famine. Loving the people as your children, you transport grain across the river. Through relief, you revive Qingzhou—your hidden virtue rivals that of the noble Fu. Through generosity, you welcome the humble—your magnanimity surpasses even that of the Duke of Zhou.

Thus, even a recluse from the mountains and forests may find a place at the sacrificial table, a crane in dark robes mistaken for a fly in ink. How dare I not, alongside my books, purify myself in the springs and rocks? Perhaps then, in my stillness, the people will be upright; in my old age, the young will find peace. May you enjoy wealth, longevity, and many sons—from Hua’s borders, I offer blessings to the emperor. May harmony and joy in office be sung in praise of the Ministry of Revenue.

I fear that if I hasten to join the ranks of the stars, I will suddenly lose the support of your two heavens. In my devotion and reliance, I have laid bare my heart.

A Reply to Vice Prefect Zhao of Linjiang

A crane in dark robes had barely glimpsed the muddied carriage-pole when a pair of fish—your letter on silk—suddenly arrived at my mountain door. Its lines gleamed bright as brocade, its gifts rained down like blessings. I read and reread without weariness, moved and enlightened in equal measure.

I once thought those of lofty conduct shunned kings and lords, that immortals wandered only through the dust of markets. Yet when I hid my southward flight on Huading Peak, noble guests came unbidden; when Lü Dongbin appeared in Yueyang, the people failed to recognize him. As for dwelling in mountains while engaging the world, or stepping beyond the city walls to present oneself—so much of life has already been lost. How could one meeting restore what was?

Recently, I heard you had been honored with a palanquin and returned in a cavalcade of riders. Though I am no Daoist master in yellow cap, how could I neglect the rites of suburban welcome? Though you descend to a scholar of humble cottage, I beheld the stature of one who stands like a mountain. My humble verses chirp like crickets or buzz like flies; my homeward dreams are of deer asleep and pheasants perched. Never did I expect such singular favor, such an honor as your fragrant letter. I carved the Heart Sutra and inscribed admonitions by night’s quiet breath, truly sharing the same essence as the sages of West Mountain. You handed me brush and ink—how could I unravel the profound thoughts of Yang Xiong?

The woven banana-leaf cloth passed lightly as five-zhu coins; the cassia-scented wine fermented in a single flask. When the provincial inspector sent gifts, all travelers marveled. I, a weary wanderer of rivers and lakes, have idly occupied the realm of springs and rocks. Fortunate to rely on you in this place, who else would speak for me?

Among the literary men of the imperial court, who would feel kinship with one in feathered cloak? Among the woodcutters on the road ahead, who would find leisure in straw sandals? I await your inspection tour, hoping to show my deepest respect.

Both the scholar and the woodcutter appear in your letter.

To Prefect Zhang of the Nearby Prefecture, Minister of Personnel

The silver hare governs the pasture; you honor the famous mountains within your borders. Children on bamboo horses welcome the new magistrate, calling back the lone crane from the clouds. Roads were cleared to await your arrival like Jia Yimin’s; passes were guarded with the reverence of Yin Xi for Laozi. All vied to be first in greeting—etiquette dictates that congratulations come before all else.

I respectfully consider your name renowned throughout the cosmos, your learning bridging heaven and humanity. Your ancestors’ tablets and your father’s robes have been inscribed on Wild Goose Pagoda for generations; your ministerial seals and scholar’s satchels have made you preeminent at Dragon Gate in this age. The emperor declared you a worthy successor and appointed you Academician. You compiled records in the imperial archives and participated in the rigorous evaluations of the Ministry of Personnel. Though clad in plain cloth, you retired from court, only to be entrusted with a new mandate. Your administrative brilliance outshone even Shen Yue’s embroidered robes; your morning sails swelled with the tide at Xiao Shoals. With five horses and no trace of gray hair, you are still in your prime. Linked to the two Lius and the three Kongs, you personally inherit their legacy. Your governance has brought such peace that I await the composition of poems celebrating harmony.

Yet I reflect on the people’s hardship: though the records show abundant harvests, taxes are levied by the acre, nearly exhausting the rice and millet of the southern fields. You seek paper mulberry along the clear river and search for pollia on fragrant isles. Old and new debts alike are treated lightly, while both public and private coffers stand empty. Without a hand swift as thunder, how could one implement policies to revive the nation? A pair of brushes has already begun to transform customs; though you stand but a foot and a half from heaven, you swiftly recommend the worthy to high office.

I humbly recall my own escape from Confucian pursuits early on, my slow progress on the Dao. I have not yet prepared the cauldron for the nine refinements, yet rashly ascended the halls of the venerable elders. I once served under military tents, handling shields and ink for dispatches; at the Golden Gate, I composed imperial responses by the light of a rush lamp. Fortunate to have requested and received the most leisurely post, I should have shut my gate and slept soundly. Instead, I mistakenly heeded the calls of my homeland’s people and was nominated to fill an empty seat. External pressures led to internal strife; how could I stand by and do nothing?

Why should I cling to this cap, when you, my lord, value my lingering presence? Others may draw their bows, but my juniors inevitably follow, jostling for advantage. I watch for your banner to halt, trusting in your clear judgment. In Yueyang, I paid respects to Zijing—not daring to be dazzled by the medicine in his gourd. Like Quan Jiao encountering Yingwu, I hope only to gather firewood from the valley floor.

In admiration and gratitude, I inscribe these words without restraint.

To Chief Prosecutor Xiao Dazhuo

chunks.original_text: 闻公子之名有日矣，方图上谒於霜台，谓处士之庐无人焉，颇觉包羞於云壑。 亟裁短贽，仰渎严威。 盖闻君子小人有同牛骥，深山大泽实生龙蛇，虽物情什伯之不齐，岂书策二三之无取。 贤如灭明，必不至於偃之室，学如子路，亦奚为於丘之门。 皇华兹贲於林塘，王气倍添於草木。 神仙弗远，但消金锁之掣开，车马曾看，未必芦花之深入。 畏摆襶向人之热，笑敲推冲尹之狂。 刺字纵漫，吾舌尽在。 忽睹析屋五花之判，几令教门一叶之轻。 彼雀角鼠牙，听讼固烦於召伯，若龙头豕腹，联诗宁乏於弥明。 不胜懵然与语之惭，殆有招之使来之意。 恭惟某儒宗学博，王佐才高，绍唐室之相家，瑀将及遘，比汉朝之人杰，吾不如何。 既跻蓬山清切之联，宜掌薇省雄严之制。 出节肯临於广部，发仓全活於饥氓。 就着绣衣，闲登席帽，翔而后集，授代之举甚高，死者复生，平反之德滋洽。 诏暑囚而亲录，言夙驾以周诹。 二使星明身俯趋於宝墠，五原雨足手倒挽於银河。 毋庸泝皇恐之滩，当俓侍通明之殿。 某谋身素拙，於道无闻，传食四方，不作蝇营而狗苟，归休一壑，可堪鹤怨以猿惊。 正抖擞於尘编，且摩挲於丹灶。 坚柴扃而麾俗客，抱瓦缶以杂畦丁。 薄闻揽辔以按行，莫敢曳裾而造请。 春秋之贬，猥及其类，左右之容，孰为之先。 异三子者，言点也，倘蒙於殊顾。 扣两端而竭鄙夫，恐坐於同科。 为客解嘲，岂予好辩。 辞岳漕 使臣辔有光，将大转木牛之粟，先生饭不足，缘新移玉女之厨。 尝闻先之齐家，果於此乎观政，其嗟可去，恶得无辞。 某维其欠负郭二顷田，不自乐陋巷一箪食，故起单於千里，遂传食於诸侯。 门外东方，何曾饱死，山头杜甫，元自瘦生。 备尝残杯冷炙之悲辛，已决早韭晚嵩之归计。 公由中而补外，客驱去而复还。 椎鼓击鲜或诧逢辰之有幸，张颐待哺焉知过午而未餐。 以涂民之耳目，为令太苛，倘累人以口腹，於礼孰重。 借令束十围蔑，亦能插几张匙。 忍听无天殷殷之雷，笑玩行地亭亭之日。 不起笔吏，谁哀王孙。 既豆羹得则生，虽草具易为食。 果念及门东之索，礼貌有亏，第诰诸灶下之炊，司存自谨。 岂期鞭扑，反逮舆台。 纵投鼠何忌之云，然打鸭之惊莫甚。 酒不及而公荣无恚，犹别亲疏。 醴忘设则穆生竟行，当明去就。 若尚怀恋豆之念，是愈负伐檀之讥。 恭惟某禀天英灵，有祖风烈，为肥甘自足於口，每苦乐快同乎人。 犒油幢百万之兵，曾趋涟水，养珠履三千之客，未逊春申。 偶然忘由己之饥，非不推食我之食。 曲行惩戒，犹示等差，与其娄琐琐细故以挠人，何患无磊磊奇士以赴我。 请从此逝，幸听其归，因黄粱而悟梦魂，休说邯鄂之富贵，有青精以好颜色，别为梁宋之遨游。 怀刺在庭，结装问路。 回太一吴都监 太一灯明，滥陪诸老，苏公堤近，因就三贤。 得之聊当於行窝，议者或讥於幽谷。 伏承某法参晋猛，诗续唐均，降滕六於中宵，恩荣象笏，挈郁仪於左手，光溢乌轮，不惟精祷祠之书，抑且造修炼之妙。 方赓酬而相乐，念离合之有时。 华以大篇，介之多馈，旁出固惭於兔窟，暮归尚借於燕巢。 唤真人莲叶之舟，可能访我，续处士梅花之句，定合输君。 感在心藏，谢容面尽。

Having long heard of your esteemed name, I had planned to pay my respects at the Prosecutor’s Terrace, only to find your reclusive dwelling seemingly unoccupied—leaving me deeply ashamed before the clouds and peaks. I hastily composed this humble offering, though I fear it may offend your solemn dignity.

For I have heard that noble and base alike may share the stable of ox and steed, and that dragons and serpents arise from deep mountains and vast marshes. Though the natures of things differ tenfold or a hundredfold, how can the records of history deem them all without merit? A worthy like Yan Ziming would never confine himself to Yan’s chamber, nor would a scholar like Zilu remain idle at Confucius’ gate. Now, with your royal splendor adorning these woods and ponds, the very grasses and trees seem to swell with imperial qi.

The immortals are not far—only the golden lock need be unlatched. Chariots and horses have been seen, yet they need not plunge deep into the reeds. I shrink from the heat of those who flaunt their robes, and laugh at the madness of those who knock on gates like the reckless magistrate. Though my tattooed words may blur, my tongue remains sharp. Yet when I glimpsed your five-flowered judgment splitting the hall, I nearly made our teaching as light as a single leaf. Those petty disputes of sparrows and rats may weary even a judge like the Duke of Shao, but when dragons’ heads and pigs’ bellies gather to compose poetry, is there ever a lack of talent like Mi Ming?

Overwhelmed by my own ignorance, I am almost compelled to heed the call to approach. I reverently consider your eminence: a pillar of Confucian learning, a scholar of vast erudition, a talent fit to serve the throne. You continue the legacy of the Tang chancellors, where even Yu nearly matched their stature, and rival the heroes of the Han, where I cannot compare. Having ascended the ranks of Penglai’s pure halls, you now wield the stern authority of the Censorate. When you deign to inspect the provinces, famine-stricken multitudes are saved by your grain distributions. Clad in your embroidered robes, at ease in your scholar’s cap, you soar before alighting—your succession a lofty act, your justice reviving the dead, your virtue spreading like a balm.

You personally review prisoners in the summer heat, rising early to consult widely. Like two stars, you hasten to the sacred altar; like the Five Plains, you draw down rain from the Silver River. No need to brave the perilous rapids of the imperial court—you shall soon stand in the Hall of Illumination.

As for myself, I am clumsy in self-governance and unknown in the Dao, a wanderer feeding on others’ charity, yet never stooping to the buzzing of flies or the fawning of dogs. Returning to my mountain retreat, I endure the laments of cranes and the startling cries of gibbons. Now, I shake the dust from my books and tend the alchemical furnace. I bar my gate to worldly guests and hold my clay pot among the garden laborers. Though I have heard of your reins being reined in for inspection, I dare not trail my robes to your door.

The Spring and Autumn’s censures extend even to those like me; who would dare presume upon your favor? Unlike the Three Disciples, I am but a speck of dust—yet if you deign to glance my way, I would exhaust both ends of my meager wit, though I fear I may still share their fate. Is this not a guest’s attempt to deflect mockery? Surely I am not one who delights in argument.

To the Grain Transport Commissioner:
Your Excellency’s bridle gleams as you prepare to dispatch the wooden-ox carts of grain, while this humble scholar’s rice pot remains empty—now that you’ve moved the Jade Maiden’s kitchen. I have heard that governing begins with ordering one’s household; here, then, is your chance to observe true administration. Alas, if I must depart, how can I do so without words?

I owe two qing of fields near the city walls, yet I never took joy in the humble lane’s single basket of food. Thus, I set out from the distant frontier, becoming a guest who feeds at the tables of lords. Beyond my gate, the Eastern Lord never starved; atop the mountain, Du Fu was ever lean. I have endured the bitterness of cold scraps and stale meat, and long since resolved to return to my early leeks and late millet. You were transferred from the capital to the provinces, while I, the guest, was driven away only to return.

Beating the drum and roasting fresh meat, I marveled at my luck in meeting such an auspicious day. Yet gaping like a fledgling awaiting food, I did not realize the hour had passed noon. To cleanse the people’s eyes and ears, your decrees may seem too harsh—yet if you burden others with their bellies’ demands, which weighs heavier in propriety? Even if you bound ten armfuls of reeds, how many ladles could they hold? How can I endure the rumbling thunder of a sky without mercy, or idly watch the sun standing tall upon the earth?

If not for the brush of the clerk, who would pity the prince’s plight? Once the bean broth is secured, life persists; though coarse fare is easily prepared. Yet if you recall the beggar at the eastern gate, my manners were lacking—though I entrusted the cooking to the kitchen, where care is naturally taken. How could I have expected the whip to fall upon the carriage attendants? Though one may "throw the rat without fear," the shock of striking the duck is far greater.

When the wine did not reach me, Gongrong bore no grudge—yet he still distinguished between kin and stranger. When sweet wine was forgotten, Mu Sheng departed at once—knowing well the time to leave. If you still harbor affection for the beans, you only deepen the mockery of "hewing sandalwood." I humbly consider your eminence: endowed with celestial brilliance, inheriting your ancestors’ noble legacy, content with simple fare for yourself, yet sharing others’ joys and sorrows. You once led a million troops with oil-bannered tents to Lian River, and your retinue of three thousand pearl-shod guests rivaled Lord Chunshen’s.

If you momentarily forgot your own hunger, it was not that you failed to share your food. Your caution in conduct still reflects distinctions—better to have no petty quarrels to trouble others than to lack the bold, unyielding knights who would rally to me. Permit me to depart henceforth, and graciously allow my return. Awakened by the millet dream, I renounce the wealth of Handan; nourished by the blue elixir, I shall roam Liang and Song instead. With my calling card still in hand and my baggage packed, I ask the way.

To Inspector Taiyi of Wudu:
The lamps of Taiyi shine brightly, and I, unworthy, have joined the elders. Su Shi’s embankment lies near, and I have sought the Three Worthies. This may serve as a temporary refuge, though critics may scorn it as a secluded valley.

I have learned that your mastery of the law rivals Jin Meng’s ferocity, and your poetry continues the Tang legacy. You summoned the Rain Master in the dead of night, honored with an ivory tablet; you grasped the sun’s essence in your left hand, its light overflowing the black wheel. Not only have you perfected the prayers of the temple, but you have also attained the subtleties of alchemical refinement. As we compose matching verses in joy, I recall that partings and meetings have their time.

Your grand compositions and generous gifts humble me, like a rabbit’s burrow beside your splendor, or a swallow’s nest borrowed at dusk. If you call the Perfected One’s lotus-leaf boat, perhaps you might visit me; if you continue the Recluse’s plum-blossom verses, you shall surely surpass me. My gratitude resides in my heart, though my thanks may never fully appear on my face.

chunks.original_text: 右街鉴义谢提举 身返斋居，仅循故步，礼成宫谢，乃俾初街。 信名器不可假人，顾富贵何有於我。 弗容还勑，殊觉厚颜。 伏念某苦无伎能，颇有气性，清心独处，难求师友之亲，白首重来，不废君臣之义。 好赐迭颁於箱篚，文词每达於冕旒。 未报主恩，幸逢宗祀，万花簇驾，获观天仗之仪，一札降廷，忽预道官之选。 论知事则米盐任责，较法师则符水通灵。 谁谓柴愚，俨同哙伍。 兹盖某事上畏谨，如道慈悲，怜千里之远来，头衔未改，忍一夫之独泣，脚迹同升。 昔闻经略之大师，今见焚修之高士。 某臂枯欲脱，囊涩休看，非钱不行，兔上贴麻之请，有书可读，但顾乞骸而归。 太一宫宫主谢提举 心清事简，谨守斋规，恩重望轻，躐参宫务，虽奏言之神速，奈材具之荒疏。 窃惟贵神所宅，甲於御前，道家者流，仰之天上。 夫何近岁颇异前闻，非惠非庄，莫识濠梁之趣。 若臧若谷，俱为博塞之游。 读《黄庭》者误字固多，点《周易》者研朱能几。 习达挑於市井，孤涵养於朝廷，欲挽颓波，必资定力。 如某者，知身有患，於世无营，既朴被以还乡，复招旌而赴阙，舍近取远，争看御笔之新除，辞尊居卑，但保青毡之旧物，效箪瓢於陋巷，忆笋蕨於春山，倍费弥纶，使填领袖，与人而问所欲，掉头即控於牢词。 知我者谓何求，觌面讫承於宠渥。 曷出诸君之右，辄居方丈之西，因闲就冗，已失本心，欲去翻留，真成缪计。 兹盖某典刑前辈，骨相臞仙。 丹暖三田，不服少年之药，香凝一室，闲看平旦之经。 佩彤弓狐矢以事君，祷桂馆竹宫而保国。 凡依栖之羽服，均披拂之春风。 某敢不洗手奉公，直躬率下，少课焚修之报，益权进退之宜。 信今日之受非，难逆大君之命，期来年然后已，幸容处士之归。 谢徐叔宽见访 解陈蕃之榻，夙慕当家，访子云之亭，忽临吾地。 惜定交之不蚤，辱委贽以甚勤。 伏惟某双剑产灵，五车饱读，体物浏亮，每叉手而赋成，传风扶摇，叹摘髭之第晚。 鼓箧熟齑盐之味，担簦揽山川之奇。 穷当益坚，威不能屈。 曰恭宽信敏惠兄弟以此五字为字，聊相对於紫荆。 从贤能俊秀升，即齐攀於丹桂。 某岩栖且老，户谁来，捧骈俪之大篇，识清修之客。 杨氏为我，谅无拔毛利天下之讥，徐卿生儿，申诵回头惊宾客之句。 永歌不足，小住为佳。 回邹元叔谢给饭牌 劝粜及山，方随苗於上产，给符自库，乃继饭於先生。 非惟见怜客之心，盖亦示隆师之意。 行供已久，言谢何迟。 恭惟某富有纸田，亲传书种，怕入长安而炊桂，肯从合皂以饭蔬。 诸弟子事兹有年，或笑从徒而安坐，大丈夫不能自食，雅应进食以疗饥。 虽殊孟子之养锺，庸免颜回之执爨。 将军未老，从者皆兴。 此日一箪匙漫抄於云子，他年五鼎柈定进於宾郎。 某夙负素囷，偶开旧店，嗟吾山之豆落，羡君谷之黍生。 母嗜铛焦归，遂承颜之乐，兄因釜颉母，贻紾臂之嫌。 去榻即悬，新条犹在。 回茅山白云观林管辖 悬榻重来，羞见堂前之青草，缄书远至，曾分岭上之白云。 当暑读之，有风清甚。 恭惟某蚤脱逢掖，勇求还丹，发言为诗类，不食烟火语，得时行道间，亦结粥饭缘。 偶然值大兵而凶年，聊尔依阿姊於明月。 伫膺一札，入践两街。

To the Right Street Supervisor of Ritual Propriety, Xie Tiju,

Returning to my vegetarian residence, I merely follow the old path; the rites completed at the palace, I am now assigned to the initial post. Truly, official rank and insignia must not be lent to others—what have wealth and nobility to do with me? To refuse the imperial decree would be shameless indeed.

I reflect that I possess no skills, only a stubborn temperament. With a pure heart, I dwell alone, finding it difficult to seek the intimacy of teachers and friends; though my hair has turned white, I have returned once more, never abandoning the righteousness between sovereign and subject. Your generous gifts repeatedly fill my chests and baskets, and your literary compositions often reach the imperial gaze. Unworthy of the sovereign’s grace, I fortunately encountered the ancestral sacrifices. Amidst the myriad blossoms clustering the imperial procession, I beheld the splendor of the celestial retinue; with a single decree issued in the court, I suddenly found myself selected among the Daoist officials. In matters of administration, I am tasked with the minutiae of rice and salt; as a ritual master, I wield talismanic water to channel the numinous. Who would have thought this dullard could stand among such esteemed company?

This is all due to your reverence for the Dao and compassion: pitying one who has come from afar, my title remains unchanged; unwilling to let even a single man weep, my footsteps ascend alongside others. Once I heard of the great strategist; now I see the lofty practitioner of austerities. My arms grow weak and nearly useless, my purse empty and unworthy of scrutiny. Without money, nothing moves—like the hare’s plea for hemp to patch its burrow. With books to read, I can only beg to return home, my bones as frail as a turtle’s.

**From the Director of the Taiyi Palace, Xie Tiju,**

With a clear mind and simple affairs, I strictly adhere to the rules of vegetarian residence. Though the favor is weighty, my standing is slight, and I overstep in managing palace affairs. While my memorials ascend swiftly, my talents are meager and untrained.

I privately consider that the divine abode you oversee ranks foremost before the throne, and the Daoist tradition is revered as if in the heavens. Yet in recent years, it has strayed from its former reputation: neither benevolent nor profound, it has lost the joy of Zhuangzi’s bridge; whether like Zang or Gu, all indulge in gambling games. Those who read the *Huangting Jing* miswrite many characters; those who annotate the *Zhouyi* scarcely apply their red ink. They learn cunning in the marketplace but cultivate solitude in the court. To stem this decline, steadfast resolve is essential.

As for myself, I know my body is afflicted, yet I seek nothing from the world. Having been summoned back to my hometown, I was again called to the capital. Forsaking the near for the distant, I vied to see the newly inscribed imperial brush; relinquishing honor for humility, I preserved only my old felt mat. Emulating the frugality of a bamboo basket and gourd ladle in a narrow alley, I long for the bamboo shoots and ferns of spring mountains. The expenses multiply, filling the gaps in my robes and collars. When asked what I desire, I shake my head and lodge a formal complaint. Those who know me ask what I seek—face to face, I receive only boundless favor.

How could I presume to stand above others, yet find myself placed west of the abbot’s quarters? Taking on trivial duties in my leisure, I have already lost my original intent. To leave would be to linger; to stay would be a misguided plan.

This is all due to the exemplary conduct of my predecessors, whose skeletal frames resembled those of emaciated immortals. The cinnabar warms the three elixir fields, yet they do not rely on youthful medicines; incense lingers in their chambers as they leisurely peruse the scriptures at dawn. Adorned with vermilion bows and fox-fletched arrows, they serve the sovereign; praying at osmanthus halls and bamboo palaces, they protect the realm. All who don the feathered robes share in the spring breeze of your guidance.

How dare I not wash my hands and serve the public, leading with an upright demeanor? I shall strive to repay the blessings of my austerities and weigh the propriety of advancement and retreat. Though I know my current appointment is undeserved, I cannot defy the sovereign’s command. I hope to resign next year, allowing this recluse to return home.

**To Xu Shukuan, in Gratitude for His Visit,**

I lowered Chen Fan’s couch, long admiring your household; you visited Yang Xiong’s pavilion, suddenly arriving at my humble abode. I regret we did not become friends sooner, yet you honored me with such earnest courtesy.

I reflect that you were born where twin swords harbor spirits, your five carts laden with books. Your understanding of things is lucid and bright; with hands clasped, you compose verses effortlessly. Borne by the whirlwind, you lament that plucking your beard came late. You have savored the flavors of pickled vegetables and salt from your satchel, and carried your staff to admire the wonders of mountains and rivers. Though impoverished, your resolve only strengthens; no power can bend you.

You take "reverence, magnanimity, trustworthiness, diligence, and kindness" as your courtesy name, facing the purple catalpa together. Among the worthy and talented, you ascend, climbing the cinnamon branches side by side.

I, who dwell in the mountains and grow old, see few visitors at my door. Yet I hold your magnificent compositions, recognizing the refined guest before me. Yang Shi’s words for me are apt—I surely avoid the criticism of plucking a hair for the world’s benefit. Xu You’s son recites the line about turning back to astonish guests. My song is never enough; a brief stay would be best.

**To Zou Yuanshu, in Thanks for the Meal Token,**

When grain distribution reached the mountains, I followed the sprouts to the upper fields; when the token was issued from the treasury, it provided meals for the master. This shows not only your compassion for a guest but also your reverence for a teacher. The provisions have been long in place; my gratitude is overdue.

I reflect that you possess vast "paper fields" and have inherited the "seeds of books." Fearing to enter Chang’an and boil cinnamon, how could I accept coarse rations? Your disciples have served for years—some mock the ease of following a master, while others, as great men unable to feed themselves, fittingly receive food to stave off hunger. Though different from Mencius’ nourishment of Zhong, I avoid Yan Hui’s cooking. The general is not yet old, and his followers are all inspired.

Today, a single bowl of rice is casually scooped from the clouds; in the future, five tripods of delicacies will surely be presented to the honored guest.

I have long borne the burden of an empty granary, occasionally opening an old shop. I sigh for the fallen beans of my mountain while envying the millet growing in your valley. My mother, fond of scorched pots, finds joy in my return; my brother, due to a tilted cauldron, incurred the resentment of a twisted arm. The couch is put away once more, though the new branches remain.

**To Lin, Administrator of the White Cloud Abbey on Maoshan,**

The couch is hung again, shaming the green grass before the hall; your letter arrives from afar, having parted with the white clouds on the ridge. Reading it in the heat, the breeze is most refreshing.

I reflect that you early shed the scholar’s robe, boldly seeking the elixir of return. Your words become poetry, your speech untouched by worldly smoke and fire. When the Dao prevails, you wander among men, forming bonds over porridge and rice. By chance, you encountered great armies and famine years, briefly relying on your elder sister beneath the bright moon.

I await a single letter, ready to tread the paths of both streets.

chunks.original_text: 某年华向凋，世味俱薄，断送未甘於官裹，游戏只在乎人间。 我自倒行，徒识子云之字，君如哂笑，同寻和靖之梅。 回周子鲁催诗 比承风驭，肯顾云扃，接尘尾之谈，信无虚士，示牛腰之轴，云是巨公。 荐贻偶俪之缄，猥索平凡之句。 方乞为寒水玉，何以报绿绮琴。 诗三百虽多奚为，徒累洪压、葛柮之仆。 母七十相依为命，缅怀嵩高、柿栗之居。 深惭短章，莫究盛事。 击唾壶而略读，覆酱瓶以无疑。 回雷应雷 归闲一壑为去国之外臣，投贽两章有扣门之热客。 问其甲子，生以庚辰，正老泉读书之年，亦康节望儿之岁。 高吟不让，远到何疑。 谓童子出视之，试验雷琴之清浊，与先生并行也，少须霞佩之颉顽。 回王秀才谢会 袖诗过我，方嗟识面之迟，樽酒延宾，乃告堕肱之厄。 维名山非容易可到，幸佳客肯联翩而来。 本期衡岳之云开，不料石头之路滑。 盖文章类脱腕之敏，而官职有折臂之祥。 偏袒而露右肩，想费良医之涂抹，持螫而用左手，还容老子之周旋。 回曾道士求挂搭 三书诣阙，焉用诗囊，六验归堂，合呈饭钞。 纵使无心而出岫，岂应空手以入山。 旧识虽多，清规难紊。 学行脚去，恐遭同舍之雕，取告身来，便驻横江之鹤。 愿文为惠，佩意良勤。 回赵签判送管辖帖 息争优老，拟变前规，求退得迁，甚非本志。 画幙重千金之享，打门惊双璧之投。 古杉欲摇，顽石亦骇。 念鸟飞之久倦，况鼯技以俱穷。 三叉路口已悔迷涂，百尺竿头焉能进步。 无阿堵物从而回买，非军资库可以寄留。 拆洛阳耆旧之书，幸察尧夫之非傲，谢乡里小儿之米，容教靖节之早归。 略具禀酬，切祈矜体。 回聂秀才 缁褐还乡，窃衣夜行之锦，珠玑掷地，谁书昼卧之裙。 偶飞梦以游仙，遂愆仪於肃客。 伏惟某名居天北，誉振湖南。 秀才三耳，忆昔过从，观音千手，失今留挽，莫遂樽酒论文之款，徒深屋梁落月之怀。 冠履袈裟，俟他时之和会，靴袍手版，勉即日之荣登。 回张副宫贺封额 鬼蚁混并，缪作双坛之长，仙龙幸会，并疏九陛之恩，未论吾教之有人，聊补此山之缺典。 伏承某应酬局熟，佐使功深，诣阙休上书，期挽河而洗甲，坐石时得句，甘捧钵以抄云，铺张大篇，光耀老眼。 某无他私意，利我公家。 紫诰黄麻，偶成勋於一旦，素书青策，犹借誉於诸方。 回陈管辖 某松篁岁晚，胶漆年多。 击竹而和踏歌，高寻仙侣，眠云而谢丹诏，远振祖风。 杂旗锣迎导之声，惠金石铿锵之句。 某发俱雪矣，笔匪椽如。 老马为驹，殊悔六州之错，后人收果，尽多九府之圜。 回黄讲师 某良心止水，讲舌生风，读易而至得妻，窃鄙屠蛟之壻，入山而遇顽石，亲见牧羊之兄。 吟诗七言，夸我二美。 某名随谤得，事以志成。 帝命维新，辱权衡於杨子，祖风可振，勉衣钵於谭君。 回王监宫 某栖心造道，余事谈兵。

My years now wane, worldly flavors all grown thin—I cannot bear to while away my days in office, yet my playful wanderings remain among men. I move backward in my ways, recognizing only the characters of Ziyun; should you laugh at me, we might together seek the plums of Hejing.

**To Zhou Ziru, who urges me to write poetry,**
I receive word of your transcendental journey—would you deign to visit this cloud-sealed retreat? Our dust-trailing conversation confirms you are no empty scholar; the scroll as thick as an ox’s waist, you say, is the work of a great master. You send me a pair of matched letters, humbly demanding my mediocre verses. I beg to be as pure as cold-water jade—how could I repay you with a lute of green silk? Though the *Three Hundred Poems* are many, what use are they? They only burden your servants, Hong Ya and Ge Duo.

My mother, at seventy, clings to me as our sole bond; I recall with longing our home beneath Song Gao’s peaks, with its persimmons and chestnuts. My poor lines shame me—they cannot do justice to your grandeur. I read them with a flick of my spittoon, then overturn the sauce jar without a doubt.

**To Lei Yinglei,**
Having retired to a secluded ravine, you are an exile beyond the court; presenting two chapters, you are a fervent guest knocking at the gate. When asked your age, you were born in the *gengchen* year—the same year Old Quan read his books, the same year Kangjie awaited his son. Your lofty recitations brook no delay—why doubt their far reach? Tell the boy to step out and test the clarity of your *lei*-zither; walk beside me, and soon you’ll vie with the jade pendants of immortals.

**To Scholar Wang, who came to visit,**
You arrived with poems tucked in your sleeve, and I lamented our late acquaintance; I welcomed you with wine, only to hear of your broken arm’s misfortune. Sacred mountains are not easily reached—how fortunate that such a fine guest deigned to arrive in quick succession! I had hoped for clouds to part over Mount Heng, but the path at Stonehead proved treacherous. For though my writing flows as swiftly as a flick of the wrist, my official post bore the omen of a broken arm. Baring my right shoulder, I imagine the cost of a skilled physician’s salves; wielding the crab’s claw with my left hand, I must still manage the old man’s affairs.

**To Daoist Zeng, seeking lodging,**
Three letters to the court—what need for a poetry satchel? Six verifications to return to the hall—present your meal alms. Even if clouds drift from the peaks without intent, can one enter the mountains empty-handed? Though old acquaintances are many, the pure rules must not be disordered. If you set out as a wandering monk, I fear your fellow lodgers will carve you up; bring your ordination certificate, and you may stay like the crane by the river. I hope for your kind favor—my gratitude runs deep.

**To Attendant Zhao, who sent a management writ,**
To end disputes and embrace old age, I sought to change past practices; to seek retirement and receive promotion—this was never my true aim. A painted curtain worth a thousand gold, a knock at the gate startling as two jades cast down. Ancient cedars tremble, stubborn stones are shaken. Long weary of flight like a bird, how much more exhausted are the tricks of the flying squirrel? At the crossroads, I already regret my lost way; on the hundred-foot pole, how can I advance further? No silver could buy my return, nor could the military treasury store my resolve. Tearing open the letter of Luoyang’s elders, I hope you see that I am no proud Yaofu; declining the rice of my hometown’s youths, I beg to emulate Jiejie’s early retreat. I offer a modest reply—pray, take pity on my condition.

**To Scholar Nie,**
Returning home in black robes, you stole the brocade of night-walking thieves; casting pearls to the ground, who would embroider the skirt of a day-sleeping scholar? By chance, a dream-flight to the immortals led me to breach etiquette in receiving a guest. I recall your name resounding in the north, your fame echoing across the southern lakes. Scholar of three ears, I remember our past exchanges; Guanyin of a thousand hands, I regret my failure to detain you. We never fulfilled our promise of wine and literary discourse—only the moon’s fall through the rafters deepens my longing. When mitre and shoes meet cassock, may we reunite in harmony; when boots and robes meet the hand-tablet, may you soon ascend in glory.

**To Vice-Palace Zhang, congratulating him on his title,**
Ghosts and ants jostle together, mistakenly made leaders of twin altars; immortals and dragons fortunately gather, jointly granted the grace of nine-tiered courts. Not that our teaching lacks men, but this fills a gap in the mountain’s rites. I hear you are adept at managing affairs, your auxiliary labors profound. You journeyed to the court to submit a memorial, hoping to wash armor in the Yellow River; sitting on stone, you composed verses, content to transcribe clouds with your alms bowl. Your grand compositions dazzle old eyes. I have no private motives—only the public good. Purple decrees and yellow hemp, by chance you’ve achieved merit in a day; plain letters and green bamboo slips still rely on the praise of all quarters.

**To Manager Chen,**
My pines and bamboos age late, my bonds of friendship endure many years. Striking bamboo to harmonize with dancing songs, I seek immortals on high; sleeping in clouds to decline the vermilion summons, I carry on the ancestral tradition afar. Amid the clamor of welcoming banners and gongs, you bestow verses resonant as metal and stone. My hair is now snow, my brush no longer like a rafter. An old horse treated as a colt—I deeply regret the errors of the Six States; later men gathering fruit—how many are as round as the Nine Treasuries’ coins?

**To Lecturer Huang,**
My good heart is still water, my lecturing tongue stirs the wind. Reading the *Yi*, I attained a wife—privately I scorned the dragon-slaying son-in-law; entering the mountains, I met stubborn stone—personally I saw the sheep-herding elder. Your seven-character poems boast of my two virtues. My name was made through slander, my affairs through resolve. The imperial command renews—you humble yourself before Yangzi’s scales; the ancestral tradition may yet flourish—strive to inherit the robe and bowl of Master Tan.

**To Supervisor Wang,**
My heart dwells in the cultivation of the Dao—my secondary concern is discussing warfare.

chunks.original_text: 续孤鹜落霞之文，身惯游於南浦，授七星斩邪之剑，派亲接於癫堂。 喜旷典之秩神，赋新篇而遗我。 某偶然集事，久矣妨贤。 张后二王，曷发才难之叹，军中一范，尚观战胜之功。 再领官事回陈溪山 太一天贵神，揖别竹宫之香火，青毡吾旧物，唤醒葛岫之烟霞。 群讥驱去而复还，谁识放行而把住。 过勤胶漆之友，宠惠珠玑之篇。 路摧车峡覆舟，固人心之难料。 水断蛟陆剸革，惟吾力之犹能。 毋袖手以旁观，庶开诚而忠告。 代上赵宪催春削 绣衣立霄汉之春，发生有日，宝塔合浮图之颖，望赐如天。 荐驰不腆之辞，拱听惟新之令。 窃考选曹之立法，最严宪节之举贤。 几州几吏率系於部封，一狱一讼审观其职业。 纵圆众剡，必出我门。 舐淮南鸿宝之丹，孰无炙色，得季布黄金之诺，谅不食言。 重念某学浅过庭，材非人幙，惟简书之是畏，幸齿发之方强。 能勿劳乎，未了痴儿之事，与其进也，甚知丈人之真。 当迎候於轻轺，即褒存於敝帚。 察九仞之泉於弃井，约斗升之水於西江。 辰来何迟，祇俟孟春之徇铎，仕如此急，或虞半夜之负舟。 忘喋喋之数穷，申拳拳之三请。 恭惟某间平闻望，伊洛渊源，用谋王断国之规，任明刑折狱之寄，周原从而历按，□石为之安留。 倚长剑於崆峒之颠，鼠子帖服，悬明镜於方皋之目，马群遂空。 繇其许可之不轻，是以搜罗而殆徧。 某辱居属籍，愿列师门。 譬传神政在阿堵之中，如插羽则便扶摇而上。 先宗盟而后异姓，维大造之有成。 待国士而报众人，非小生之所敢。 归依至切，敷控奚殚。 代干制帅史尚书荐举 拥帅幢，开制阃，大江均戴於使天，攀相衮，叙年家，小草辄投於恩地。 顾下寮之尘土，仰荧座之星辰。 忘其等威，控此悃恼。 窃考累朝龙虎之榜，号多士则有之，若求两家鸿雁之行，俱三人者鲜矣。 鼎立临江之孔，台联番水之洪，从夸竞秀之荣，谁笃同登之契。 维先君而二父，托端殿之一门。 半刺史携客而上郁孤，最崇交於绣幙。 今丞相省亲而道湓浦，特枉顾於缇屏。 书云情犹兄弟而姓不同，意者施及子孙而恩罔替。 然骨骼龙猪之别，故飞翱鹏鴳之殊。 可言而言，谓进则进。 伏念某斗筲何算，寸线无长，锁应厕名仅取踏槐之效，棘围还试尚希赐笏之传。 偶遗霈之沾濡，即微官而束缚。 读荆国临川之集，访萧洲文选之楼。 贵人欲出我门，猥蒙推挽，痴儿待了公事，靡惮勤劳。 拳拳食蘖以饮冰，望望雘丹而涂塈。 在脱选莫难於职剡，而乞灵尝扣於采庭。 躬洒报亟，慨垂重诺。 捧崇垣之疾置，增陋廨之荣光。 与其挟刘公之书熏莸同器，孰若致伯鱼之问桃李成蹊。 庶因万石之澣裙，乐以千金而享帚。 恭惟某禀於天者浑厚，辅以学而高明。 身在沙堤，习见凤池之衣钵，量阔溟海，平吞蜃气之楼台。 十年不出於长安，八座峻跻於冢宰。 属边头之多燧，宜江面之无波。 用铺敦淮濆之规模，移弹压辇毂之手段。 旨麾羽扇，布置楼船，军声大振於柳营，虏众悉潜於草地。 宽九重之忧顾，赞百揆之畴庸。 父爱之子亦爱之，奇士夙延於东阁。 主贤者客必贤者，愚人或取於西家。 某托门墙僭沥其鼠肝，类弹者冒求於鸮炙。 愿损有余之惠，曲矜不肖之孤。 卑篑土以成山，免仞泉而弃井。

Extending the prose of lone wild duck and autumnal glow, my body grows accustomed to roaming South Bank; receiving the Seven-Star Sword to slay demons, my lineage directly connects to the Hall of Madness. Delighted by the grand canon’s divine ordinance, you composed a new ode and bestowed it upon me. I, by chance, have gathered affairs—long have I hindered the worthy. The two kings after Zhang—how they evoked the lament of untapped talent; the one Fan in the army—still we witness his triumphant merit. Again assuming official duties, I return to report to Minister Chen of the Mountains and Streams. The Supreme Heaven’s Noble Spirit, I bow in parting from the incense and flame of the Bamboo Palace; the green felt is my old possession, awakening the mist and clouds of Mount Ge’s peaks.

The crowd mocks my expulsion and return—who recognizes the letting go and holding fast? My friends, steadfast as glue and lacquer, bestow upon me the favor of pearls and jades in verse. Roads crumble, carriages overturn in gorges, boats capsize—truly the human heart is hard to fathom. Water severs dragons, land cleaves hides—only my strength yet endures. Do not stand idle as a bystander; rather, open your sincerity and offer loyal counsel.

**Reply to Censor Zhao Urging Spring’s Arrival**
The embroidered robe stands in the celestial spring—renewal has its day; the jeweled pagoda crowns the stupa’s tip—your grace towers like heaven. My humble words, though unworthy, hasten forth; I await with clasped hands your renewed decree. Privately I examine the Selection Bureau’s statutes—none are stricter than the举贤 of the Censorate. Several prefectures, countless officials, all depend on your seal; every case, every lawsuit, scrutinized for their duties. Though the crowd may be sharp as blades, they must emerge from my gate. Who, licking the elixir of Huainan’s *Hongbao*, lacks the glow of alchemy? Who, having received Ji Bu’s golden vow, would dare break faith?

Deeply I consider: my learning is shallow, my father’s teachings scant, my talent unfit for the tent of men. Only the imperial edict do I fear; fortunately, my teeth and hair remain strong. Can I not labor? The affairs of a foolish son remain unfinished. Yet in advancing, I know well the elder’s truth. I shall await your light carriage in welcome, even as I cherish my humble broom. Examine the nine-fathom spring in the abandoned well; draw but a ladle’s water from the West River. Why this delay? I await only the first month’s proclamation of the bell. Service presses so urgently—lest I fear the midnight boat’s departure. Ceasing my endless chatter, I renew my earnest threefold plea.

**Respectfully considering you:**
Your reputation for fairness is long-established, your lineage flows from the Luo and Yi. Applying the strategies of kings and the decisions of states, entrusted with the duty of illuminating punishments and adjudicating cases, you traverse the Zhou plains in inspection—even the *que* stones remain steadfast. Leaning your long sword atop Kongtong’s peak, the rats submit; suspending your bright mirror before Fanggao’s gaze, the herd of horses vanishes. Since your assent is never lightly given, your search for talent is nearly exhaustive.

I, unworthy, dwell in your kinship’s register, aspiring to stand within your master’s gate. As governance’s spirit resides in that single point, so too, with a feather’s insertion, one swiftly ascends. First honor the ancestral covenant, then the bonds of other surnames—only in great creation is there completion. Awaiting a state’s knight to repay the common crowd—this is not a humble student’s dare. My devotion is most earnest; how could I exhaust my supplications?

**Reply to Minister Shi, Military Commissioner, on Recommendation**
Hoisting the commander’s banner, opening the commissioner’s frontier, the great river equally bears the emperor’s mandate; grasping the prime minister’s robe, recounting our familial years, even the humble grass prostrates upon the ground of favor. Gazing up from the dust of my lowly station, I behold the stars of your resplendent seat. Forgetting rank and dignity, I present my sincerity and distress.

Privately I examine the dragon-and-tiger lists of successive dynasties—though they boast many scholars, those who attain the wild geese’s formation in both families, three men each, are rare indeed. The three-legged cauldron stands by the Jiang’s Kong; the terrace links Hong of the Fan waters. Among those who vie in boasting their excellence, who deepens the pact of shared ascent? Through my late father and two elders, we are bound to the same gate. Half a prefect, I once accompanied guests up Yu Gu; our loftiest bond was beneath the embroidered tent. Now the prime minister visits his kin along the Pen’s banks—how graciously you deign to glance upon my vermilion screen!

The *Book* says: "In affection like brothers, though surnames differ"—perhaps your kindness extends to descendants without end. Yet the distinction between dragon bones and swine is clear; thus the soaring of roc and wren diverge. To speak when one may—this is to advance.

**Humbly reflecting:**
My capacity is but a dou or shao, my thread of talent short. The lock responds to my name, barely achieving the effect of treading the scholar’s tree; the thorn enclosure’s test still awaits, hoping for the transmission of the ivory tablet. By chance I was touched by your beneficent rain, thus bound in this minor office. Reading the collections of Jingguo and Linchuan, I visited the *Wenxuan* tower of Xiaozhou. A noble person desires my emergence from your gate—how undeservedly I am drawn forth! A foolish son awaits the completion of your affairs—undaunted by toil.

Earnestly I gnaw the bitter herb and drink the ice, gazing toward the cinnabar and plaster. In selection’s release, nothing is harder than the blade’s edge; in seeking divine aid, I have knocked at the courtyard of the Cai. Personally I hasten to repay swiftly, moved by your solemn vow. Receiving your lofty mandate in haste, I enhance the humble office’s glory.

Rather than clutching Lord Liu’s book while foul and fragrant share the same vessel, better to elicit Master Bo’s inquiry—peach and plum trees form a path. Perhaps through the washing of the ten-thousand-stone’s robes, I may joyfully wield a thousand gold’s broom.

**Respectfully considering you:**
Endowed by heaven with profundity, refined by learning to loftiness, your body resides on the sandy embankment—accustomed to the phoenix pond’s robes and bowls; your measure vast as the ocean, calmly swallowing the mirage’s towers. Ten years you did not leave Chang’an; eight seats you ascended as minister of state. With border beacons ablaze, the river’s surface should remain unruffled. Applying the model of Huai’s banks, you transfer the hand that presses the imperial carriage. Wielding the banner and feather fan, arranging the towered ships, the army’s might resounds in the willow camp—enemy hordes vanish into the grasslands. Easing the ninefold emperor’s cares, you assist the hundred officials’ tasks.

The father’s beloved son is also beloved—extraordinary scholars have long been welcomed in the eastern pavilion. Where the lord is worthy, the guest must be worthy—even a fool may be taken from the western house. I, relying on your gate’s walls, presumptuously drip my mouse liver, like the cicada’s suitor seeking owl’s roast. I pray you temper your abundant grace, bending to pity this unworthy orphan. Piling humble baskets of earth to form a mountain, I avoid abandoning the fathom-deep spring for the well.

Born in the garden of Master Shi, raised among the steeds of Bo Le—why bow and scrape to others when I may attend your lordship’s sandals? The oath of the Wen State hall endures in this world. Gradually I seek to take root and stand firm, to repay the shaping hand of the potter’s wheel.

When the royal inspector summoned the recluse from his mountain, he still occupied the seat of the chief minister. Dispatching a messenger to the distant frontier, they hastened his return to the study chamber. Ascending the carriage post was like casting dice to select an official; approaching the palace gate resembled a macaque entering its pouch. By chance I washed away the shame of the hidden valley, or perhaps I invited mockery for taking a shortcut.

Honored with poetic verses, I deeply cherish this bond of friendship. Now, shifting my courtyard to rein in the world’s customs, how dare I encroach upon your seat to answer the visiting star? Compared to the talent of "eight dou to one dan," my words recklessly boast beyond Cao Zijian’s; observing a stature of nine chi and four cun, my achievements should belong to Cao Jiao.

Should we journey east together, we would surely ascend to the heights.

*End of Volume One of the Collected Works of Master Wu Zhai*
*Volume Two of the Collected Works of Master Wu Zhai*

By imperial decree, the Reclusive Scholar Yang Zhizhi of Heishan, bearing the title *Right Attendant for the Mirror of Righteousness and Supervisor of Daoist Affairs*, respectfully submits this memorial in gratitude for his appointment to a temple post.

Having long retired to rustic fields, I dared to bask in the sun of your esteemed summons. Recalled to court, I finally acceded to the temple’s request. My duties, though nominal, bring honor; my stipend, though modest, sustains my poverty. Moved by the emperor’s grace, I humbly express my private gratitude.

I reflect: born in a remote village, my nature is ordinary. While I have long cherished the bonds of teachers and friends, how could I aspire to serve the ruler or benefit the people? Barely repaying my village debts, I still owe my service to the prefectural office. Afflicted by illness, I sought retirement, idly consuming the state’s grain. Though I should have retired by age, I remain attached to this enlightened era.

When the sagely emperor personally took the reins to inaugurate a new era, the virtuous were elevated to aid governance. He inquired after scholars, summoning the eight worthies by name. Though I declined the casket’s offer, edicts repeatedly arrived. Phoenixes and swans gathered—permitted to follow in the footsteps of the immortals on Mount Dao—yet my aged hound and horse, too feeble to behold the celestial gates, repeatedly pleaded from within. At last, my earnest pleas were met with compassion. Honored with the Eastern Wall’s books, entrusted with the Central Altar’s incense, I never left my rural home, yet my name was inscribed among the ranks of officials.

What weight do I hold in the court of Duke Yu? My old age is doubly burdened by fate. More than satisfied, I call this an encounter with fortune. If I were to compile annotations, I would exhaust my life’s energy. The golden casket’s teachings for my son suffice for family study; the bamboo slips sent to the prefecture were mistakenly summoned for imperial proclamation. Shallow and unworthy, I contribute nothing to glory.

This is all thanks to your renown resounding across China and beyond, your merits securing the altars of state. You personally embrace the sun of Yu Yuan, calmly dispelling the clouds of the Yellow Road. Like Tang learning from Yi Yin to serve as minister, your virtue truly reaches heaven; like Shun elevating Gao Yao from the multitude, your ancient plans are reaffirmed. Laboring to renew a hundred neglected affairs, with a gesture you advance the careers of all officials. Though I am but a withered remnant, I share in this honor.

How dare I not strive to witness the Great Peace, prolonging my fading years? I intend to compose praises for the sagely ruler and worthy ministers, joining the joy of yellow-haired elders and white-headed children. Though my back warms in the sun, I still harbor the ambition to offer myself to the lord; though my cap hangs late, I shall follow with a memorial of resignation.

---

*In Gratitude for the Appointment of Zhao Dazi as Maritime Pacification Commissioner*

I reverently note that the imperial court has issued its decree, and the frontier command has stilled its might. Clad in brocade, you return home—four generations hasten to court at the Wei Gate; a soldier strays from his ranks, yet a single word pacifies the crisis within the palace walls. The seas lie calm, and the emperor’s countenance is joyful.

I hold in esteem your brilliance and distinction, your depth and breadth. Who among the world’s talents stands to your right? Deploying the arsenal within your breast, none can withstand you. For a decade along the Yangtze and Huai, through a hundred battles with banners and drums, your strategies severed the Xiongnu’s arm; your laughter brought the head of Zhi Zhi. Great merit blazes on your banners, while you find tranquil delight among springs and rocks.

Yet the times are troubled—how could you remain idle long? The land of Shu seems vast; you rouse a zither like Qing Xian. When neighbors quarrel, you astonish them with three arrows like the general. Now, guiding the reins with care, you swiftly lay down your weapons to receive their homage. Were it not for the support of the Luoyang and Shetai officials, one might suspect the Yellow Pool’s soldiers still stir unrest.

Officials flock to your court; the emperor leans forward in his seat. The Yandui rapids, like elephants, now serve the ships of Eastern Wu; the Wei River’s non-bear omens hasten your grasp of the western pivot’s handle. Quelling the beacon fires at the borders, you strengthen the state’s foundation like a massive boulder.

I, a latecomer from the southern rivers, have yet to tread the imperial avenue. Though I have not ascended the Dragon Gate, how could I bear the chariot’s journey? Reading the green silk dispatches, I marvel at the purple aura. Whose appearance resembles Duke Jin’s? Perhaps I may harmonize with the welcoming party by the roadside. How much grain does the Grand Minister possess? I offer a plan for the Guanzhong region. In celebrating your appointment, I have no more to add.

---

*In Gratitude for the Appointment of Zhao Dazi as Pacification Commissioner of the East*

I reverently note that the azure heavens have bestowed the battle-axe, and the purple palace has transferred the jade bridle. Your seat surpasses the plans Jia Yi once presented. Delaying your morning audience across nine steps, you govern the east of Shaan as the Duke of Zhou did. Seated amidst a thousand peaks, you grandly unfold the tented headquarters’ regulations, secretly conveying blessings to the capital.

I hold in esteem your spirit, born between sea and mountain, a pillar of the imperial house. Your talents and aura are unmatched—none among the mediocre can compare. Your fame resounds; you have swallowed the Xiongnu of the northern frontier whole. Shielding the Yangtze and sheltering the Huai, your strategies are well-ordered; enriching the state and strengthening the army, your merits are resplendent.

Occasionally indulging in the pleasures of Pingquan, you leisurely peruse the maps of Luoshe. The king says, "Return swiftly!"—you soothe the apes of Jiange; a soldier strays from his ranks—you quell the hedgehogs of the willow camp. Better to hold a spring purification festival in late spring than cross the Lu River in May.

Now, the imperial edict changes your role, planting you in the imperial homeland. The palace’s celestial foundations extend the emperor’s mandate for ten thousand years; the towers’ cloud-reflected shadows gather the immortals of Penglai’s three islands.

chunks.original_text: 风流文物全属遨头，期会簿书不烦老手。 稍奏保厘之绩，亟跻宥密之联。 某缪听朝鸡，遂共流马，愧咨诹之何有，唯旷败之是虞。 欣聆历吉以启藩，甚幸依邻而席芘。 旗旄可望，药石攸资。 陪元戎出野亭，徒想镜湖之集，观奇士留东阁，尚随辈路之尘。 赞傒俱深，敷陈罔究。 代贺淮东总领兼镇江吴侍郎 某恭审抗旃领饷，持槖专城，印何累累，王人跨诸侯之序，鄂不韡韡，兄弟继冯君之歌。 台府鼎新，衣冠甚盛。 恭惟某紫垣魁宿，薄海人，有天地，有君臣，造《大学》《中庸》之道，言文章，言政事，登承明侍从之班。 妙年历历於清华，敏手恢恢於繁剧。 天当平治，帝曰畴咨。 二千石朱两轓，岂薄江东之道院，三十锺致一斛，适多塞上之军屯。 心灯相续於大苏，烽火不惊於细柳。 以无双之材气，压第一之江山。 兵食足，民信之，刀剑尽还於牛犊。 戎狄和，国福也，干戈伫裹以虎皮。 遄归紫橐之联，径陟黄扉之拜。 某辈刍无补，蠹粟滋惭，温游北固之楼台，自笑东华之尘土。 耸闻异数，敢叙同寅。 天下称吴，窃晞踪於循吏，军中有范，仍拭目於肤公。 赞抃居深，敷刊罔究。 代贺淛西提刑魏少监 某恭审遴简笋班，分持绣节。 曰甸服五百里，臣惟命之东西，谓国用三十年，楮与时而高下。 临遣授变通之策，称提增举刺之权。 星驾有行，泉流无壅。 恭惟某襟期掀豁，风范温凝，迩事父，远事君，深雅颂四诗之教。 上治内，下治外，洞军戎万里之情。 彩缨历篷於鹓鸾，除器且专於兰锜。 高折广寒之桂，载赓闻喜之诗。 白玉为堂，演纶有待，黄金如土，救币莫前。 小烦汉使之咨诹，立见周家之殷富。 直天子图书之府，未隔清光，空庶人刑狱之牢，式符明指。 亟被膝前之召，益崇肺附之亲。 某畴昨侍朝，於今联治。 历历游从之款，依依离索之怀。 簸扬之枇糠在前，敢忆憩棠之旧。 臭味也草木於我，毋忘诲药之忠。 赞系欲言，剪裁莫究。 代贺史侍郎知平江兼提举 某恭审疏荣魏阙，移镇吴门。 荡节风生，继衮衣之先躅，雌堂昼永，赓画戟之清吟。 台府并新，吏民交庆。 恭惟某神姿凝粹，德寓恢洪。 八叶名家，亲宝相门之笏，一经教子，密传道学之灯。 方当文度居膝上之时，尽得陈平宰天下之说。 论思益峻，培养加深。 水断蛟，陆剸犀，出神锋於宝匣，前鞭鸾，后棰凤，骋逸驾於华涂。 频分半竹之符，久报嘉禾之政。 充仁心於父母，凛清操於冰霜。 童子中和之歌转闻而上，公卿选表之用盍归乎来。 帝念姑苏之民，地大扶风之郡。 迎送疲於数易，抚摩庶其少苏。 双旌启藩，万物吐气。 摘山煮海不妨拜使者之厅，听履持衡即入侍玉皇之案。 某登畿最晚，诹阳何堪，梦欲断於朝鸡，技且穷於鼯鼠。 幸光华之密迩，均荫赖之扶疏。 同官为寮，敢附甘泉之法从，国士待我，定怜东阁之旧人。 赞倚有怀，敷誊罔既。 代喜雪贺宰执 某伏以四时成岁，冬且至以生阳，一德享天，云亟同而雨雪。 乾坤益瑞，海宇均欢。 恭惟某密运大钧，力凝和气，考金禳之占野，闵铁甲之屯边。 谓宿麦连云，欲仍驱於厉鬼，则飞花剪水，必严饰於玄冥。 凑绣纹一线之添，庆瑶陛六霙之集。 某缪共漕转，与睹休祥。 嘉颖归周端叶丰年之梦，潜枚缚蔡嗣听捷昼之音。

The refined culture and elegant affairs all belong to the leader of the outing; the gatherings and official records do not trouble the seasoned hand. Having briefly achieved accomplishments in governance and pacification, you swiftly ascend to the inner circle of imperial trust.

I, who have mistakenly heard the morning cock’s crow and thus shared the journey with the imperial carriage, feel shame at having no counsel to offer, and fear only my own negligence and failure. Delighted to hear of your auspicious appointment to open the fief, I am most fortunate to rely upon a neighboring seat as your colleague. Your banners and standards may be glimpsed from afar, and your remedies and stones are ever at hand.

Accompanying the marshal to the suburban pavilion, I can only imagine the gatherings by Mirror Lake; observing the extraordinary scholar retained in the eastern chamber, I still follow in the dust of your company. My admiration is profound, yet my words fail to express it fully.

On behalf of the congratulatory address to the Grand Supervisor of Huaidong and Military Commissioner of Zhenjiang, Wu the Vice Minister:

I respectfully note that you raise the banner and oversee provisions, holding the satchel and governing the city. Your seals are stacked high, and the imperial envoys rank among the feudal lords; your prestige shines brightly, and your brothers continue the songs of Feng Jun. The offices and prefectures are newly established, and the gentry flourish.

I reverently consider that you, a leading star of the Purple Enclosure, are renowned across the seas. In the realm of heaven and earth, and of ruler and minister, you embody the Dao of the *Great Learning* and the *Doctrine of the Mean*; in literature and governance, you ascend the ranks of the imperial attendants in Chengming Hall. In your youth, you traversed the halls of purity with distinction; with nimble hands, you managed the most complex affairs.

Heaven ordains peace and order, and the emperor seeks counsel. As a high official with two crimson carriages, you do not disdain the Daoist abbeys of Jiangdong; with thirty bushels measured to the peck, you aptly supply the military garrisons of the northern frontier. The lamp of the mind continues the great awakening, and beacon fires cause no alarm at the Willow Camp. With unparalleled talent and spirit, you command the foremost land south of the Yangtze.

With ample supplies and the people’s trust, swords are returned to oxen and plows. With the Rong and Di at peace, the nation is blessed, and shields are wrapped in tiger skins. Swiftly returning to the ranks of the purple satchels, you ascend directly to the yellow gates of the imperial court.

We, mere straw and chaff, offer no aid, and our consumption of the state’s grain deepens our shame. Wandering the towers of Beigu, we laugh at the dust of Donghua. Hearing of extraordinary honors, we dare to recount our shared service. The realm praises Wu, and we secretly admire the footsteps of the virtuous officials; the army has its Fan, and we await with eager eyes the deeds of the esteemed lord.

Our joy is profound, yet our words cannot fully express it.

On behalf of the congratulatory address to Wei the Vice Director of the Zhexi Judicial Commission:

I respectfully note that you have been selected for the bamboo ranks and entrusted with the embroidered tally. Within the five hundred *li* of the royal domain, you serve as commanded, east or west; for thirty years of state expenditure, paper currency rises and falls with the times. Upon dispatch, you are given strategies for adaptability, and your authority to inspect and supervise is enhanced. The starry carriage moves forth, and the springs flow without obstruction.

I reverently consider that your aspirations are vast and your demeanor warm and composed. Near at hand, you serve your father; afar, you serve your lord, deeply embodying the teachings of the *Ya* and *Song* in the Four Poems. Above, you govern the inner court; below, you govern the outer realm, penetrating the sentiments of the military across ten thousand *li*. Your colored tassels have passed through the ranks of the phoenix and egret; your weapons are already entrusted to the orchid-scented armory. You have plucked the osmanthus of the broad moon and now continue the *Wenxi* poems. The hall is built of white jade, awaiting the unfolding of imperial decrees; gold is as common as dust, and no one precedes you in rescuing the state’s currency.

Even the inquiries of the Han envoys would be swiftly answered, revealing the abundance of the Zhou dynasty. Directly within the emperor’s library of maps and books, your radiance is not obscured; emptying the prisons of the common people, you align with the enlightened directives. Swiftly summoned to the emperor’s side, you are further honored with the intimacy of a trusted advisor.

I, who once attended court with you, now share in your governance. The memories of our companionship are vivid, and the sentiments of parting linger. The chaff of my insignificance lies before me; how dare I recall the old days of resting beneath the scholar’s tree? Yet, like grass and trees to me, your fragrance endures—do not forget the loyalty of your medicinal teachings.

My admiration is boundless, yet my words are cut short.

On behalf of the congratulatory address to Vice Minister Shi, Governor of Pingjiang and concurrently Supervisor:

I respectfully note that you have been honored with an imperial appointment and transferred to govern Wumen. Your virtuous standards stir the wind, continuing the footsteps of the imperial robes; the halls are bright by day, and the painted halberds echo with pure recitations. The offices and prefectures are renewed, and officials and people rejoice together.

I reverently consider that your spirit is pure and your virtue vast. From a family of eight generations of renown, you inherit the ivory tablets of the imperial court; with a single classic, you teach your sons, secretly transmitting the lamp of Daoist learning. Even when Wendou was upon your knee, you mastered Chen Ping’s strategies for governing the realm. Your counsel is ever more refined, and your cultivation ever deeper.

On water, you sever dragons; on land, you cleave rhinoceroses, drawing the divine blade from its jeweled scabbard. Ahead, you spur the phoenix; behind, you lash the simurgh, driving the swift carriage upon the splendid path. Frequently entrusted with the half-bamboo tally, you have long reported the auspicious governance of Jiahe. Your benevolent heart embraces the people as parents, and your pure integrity is as unyielding as ice and frost.

The songs of harmony from the children ascend on high, and the selection of officials by the court must surely turn to you. The emperor, mindful of the people of Gusou, compares it to the vast prefecture of Fufeng. Weary from frequent changes in governance, the people hope for some respite. With your paired banners unfurled, all things exhale their breath.

Boiling the mountains and seas does not hinder your reception in the envoys’ hall; holding the scales and wearing sandals, you ascend to attend the Jade Emperor’s court.

I, who arrived in the capital most recently, am unworthy of even the sun’s warmth. My dreams are severed by the morning cock, and my skills are exhausted like the squirrel’s. Yet, fortunate to bask in your radiance so closely, I share in the shelter of your spreading shade. As colleagues in office, I dare to follow in the imperial procession to Ganquan; as a scholar awaiting your favor, I am surely an old acquaintance of the eastern chamber.

Our admiration is heartfelt, yet our words are incomplete.

On behalf of the congratulatory address to the Chief Ministers upon the joyous snowfall:

For the Winter Solstice Congratulating the Eminent Prince:
I reverently consider that the Han inherited the celestial mandate, and its calendar extends into ten thousand years; winter yields to the year’s dawn, and the yang indeed returns on the seventh day. How grand is the founding elder of the imperial lineage, how fitting the auspicious omen of the river’s flow. I humbly regard you, whose virtue gleams like ice in a jade vessel, whose renown soars high as the handle of the Dipper. The king addresses you as “Uncle,” and you are enfeoffed with lands vast as the thatched hut’s domain; Heaven bestows upon the good man a lifespan as steadfast as the pine and cedar. In response to the embroidered brocade’s added thread, I offer the silken cord bearing treasures. I, who dwell in the fields and inquire of customs, know the shelter of summer when winter’s chill descends. The wooden oxen and flowing horses—how could they bear the warmth of military quilts? The jade belt with dangling fish—how I long only to draw near the imperial couch.

For the Winter Solstice Congratulating Vice-Director Shi of Pingjiang:
I reverently consider that the phoenix tower records the clouds, harmonizing with the catalpa’s floss to mark the season; Tiger Hill lifts its snow, casting radiance upon the banners and standards. As we welcome the waxing of the yang force, abundant blessings converge in great measure. I humbly regard you, whose pure wind disciplines the officials, whose benevolent sun befits the people. In the eastern pavilion, the plum blossoms’ song still recalls the taste of the broth you seasoned; in the purple hall, the jade chimes resound as you take your place in the courtly ranks. Soon you will be granted the jade ring and permitted to inquire with your tablet in hand. I, who seek counsel yet offer little aid, have long relied on your sheltering care. The lanes and alleys hang lanterns, and I recall past wanderings in the grand prefecture; the palace courts resound with celebration, as we welcome the new imperial favor at the lofty gates.

For the Returned Congratulations to the Prefect of Qingyuan on the Winter Solstice:
I note that the Lu observatory records the clouds stirring the catalpa’s floss to mark the season, while the Yin Tower lifts its snow, illuminating the repaired banners with radiance. As we welcome the waxing of the yang force, abundant blessings converge in great measure. I humbly regard you, whose pure wind disciplines the officials, whose benevolent sun befits the people. In the eastern pavilion, the plum blossoms bloom, continuing the mountain’s defiance of the cold; on West Lake, the ice congeals, evoking memories of leaning on the balustrade beneath the moon. I await the bestowal of Huang Ba’s gold, and the return of the jade pendants from the purple hall. I, who seek counsel yet offer little aid, have long relied on your sheltering care. Following you along the courtly paths, I vainly recall the traces of jade and jasper; in the new hall, receiving guests, I still hear the strains of strings and flutes. My admiration and praise know no bounds, yet my words fail to encompass them.

For the Returned Congratulations to the Prefect of Jiaxing on the Winter Solstice:
I note that the phoenix tower records the clouds, verifying the subtle yang in the jade tubes, while Mandarin Duck Lake’s flying snow illuminates the auspicious colors on the commander’s flags. As we welcome the waxing of the yang force, abundant blessings converge in great measure. I humbly regard you, whose half-term as prefect has changed, yet whose prayers have inspired songs of praise. Near the five-chi heavens, the land gains weight through your presence; measuring the three-zhang shadows, governance renews with the season. Soon you will present the ceremonial slippers and socks, and return to the joy of filling the curtained halls. Towering over the literary stones, you will closely attend the sweet springs. I, who measure my worth and find it lacking, have long relied on your sheltering care. In the splendid hall, the clamor of music brings joy as I hear of the return of the vital breath; in the extraordinary fields, the harvest of grain prompts the submission of a report on the year’s abundance. In offering my praises, my words fail to suffice.

From the Vice-Magistrate of Lin’an in Gratitude to the Chief Ministers:
I consider that in this rocky district, I govern the people, barely escaping official censure; in the divine suburbs, I am suddenly honored with an appointment as vice-magistrate. Though the land is near, its standards are lofty, and I am ashamed that my person is humble and my talents shallow. The great potter’s wheel turns, yet how can I, mere mud on the axle, bear such a burden? Privately, I reflect that as the deputy of the heavenly prefecture, my carriage bears the title of “lesser prefect”; in the single metropolis of Qiantang, the court is closely surrounded. Though the staff may exceed three halls, the decisions truly concern the myriad affairs. For the pacification of the imperial chariot’s path, I serve as assistant and elder—this is no mere division of scenic delights to boast of to others. In the distant past of the Xining era, Su Shi occupied this seat; more recently, in the Jiading era, a remonstrating minister emerged from this post. chunks.original_text: 伏念某清苕晚进，小草微踪。 插架书多，敢堕绮执之习，堆床笏少，居怀弓冶之羞。 一同远试於瓯闽，三载偶沉於桴鼓。 初无政最，何有言扬。 全璧东归，爰索长安之米，扫门上谒，冒陈光范之书。 纵治中六百石，犹阶而可升，如城南尺五天，则梦所不到。 赖提挈之力大，蒙造化之功深。 日往月来，毋多侍戎，朝发夕至，真是便家。 非惟抚鹡鸰之原，得诲孤而治葬，抑少憩鸡豚之社，容息蹇以磨铅。 当此侥踰，若为报塞。 兹盖恭遇某八荒开域，一柱擎天，萧也规，曹也随，历历奋庸而熙载。 房之谋，杜之断，惓惓修政以攘夷。 器名每谨於繁缨，人物率归於夹袋。 有如块矿，均沐埏镕。 某敢不佩服隆私，持循先训，庶题舆而佐岳，稍结绶以登畿。 展骥何为，听槐街之鞭策，登龙甚幸，厕材馆之簪裾。 誓毕微生，仰酬厚德。 代回沿海制置赵都承 某恭审敛谟宥密，进撰凝严，谋帅谁先，汉臣无出谊之右，在师中吉，周公其主陕之东。 辞玉陛而有行，合天朝而交庆。 恭惟某胸蟠万卷，笔倒三江，自其少年，蚤负台阁之望，安於平进，历更麾节之劳。 当朝廷救楮之时，应君子拔茅之象。 密勿百寮之上，周旋二柄之间。 过政事堂，丞相每改容而听，用春秋法，史臣仍载笔而书。 方将登法从簪橐之班，相与定匈奴金缯之议。 若时古鄮，有事春搜。 校六步七步之愆，士辄哗而失伍，膺再命三命之宠，公甚壮而临藩。 前茅戒严，细柳改色，亲授青冥之钺，闲围别墅之棋。 昌黎入廷凑之军信儿郎之帖服，光弼代子仪之将见旗帜之精明。 亟听褒嘉，归陪论献。 某侍朝甚幸，将漕无堪。 政依枢柄之余辉，拟预月楼之清集。 况朱幡之出镇，欣紫绶之增华。 羁怀窃感於别离，盛礼敢当於骈俪。 着鞭先我，自怜骨一相之屯，折柳送君，剩祝功名之会。 襟期所共，心画奚殚。 代回严州卫守 恭审作命典藩，简辰植纛。 书登金鐀，密联东壁之辉，车拥朱幡，高压客星之次。 叔度之来何暮，文正之踪有光。 恭惟某学富邺签，姿凝昆玉。 俨若思，毋不敬，威仪素习於三千。 进乎道，恢有余，肯綮蚤经於十二。 振伯仲埙简之誉，擅春秋兰菊之芳。 宜在朝廷，乃更州县。 遡牙樯於清濑，森棨戟於上游。 田庐间苦於白催，帑廪颇从而赤立。 规模自我，必易局以置棋。 手段过人，尽无面而作饼。 稍修数月之令，亟腾五袴之歌。 入为公卿，净洗兵甲。 某使华曷称，王事徒劳，镜中之发既星，江头之潮如屋。 政拟擘笺而贺上，遽蒙惠翰之来前。 忆千骑之过都，仅一觞而临水。 观风畿左，长哦结辈参错之诗。 假道棠阴，行遂渊明归来之兴。 报襄弗恪，詹乡加廑。 代回安吉州赵监丞 恭审选贤班缀，分牧京畿。 得结辈十数人，荣佩银菟之印，封姬姓八百国，清占水精之宫。 下车有初，比屋相庆。 恭惟某行高天揖，量大渊渟。 博洽多闻，映太一青藜之杖，风流自命，披谪仙紫绮之裘。 人知直上以干霄，我则徐行而按辔。 既飞见而展骥，载骑马以听鸡。 禁鸾东床，饱观奇士。 判花西掖，盍列从臣。 肯盘薄於一麾，试招徕於六客。 吏事绰然余地，歌谣蔼其近天。 燕寝凝香，伫报龚黄之政，都堂并席，定追富晏之踪。 某漕转无堪，知怜有素，忆从容而扣阁，欣振厉以开藩，不因过客而饰厨，岂复追胥之打户。

I prostrate myself in reflection: my origins are humble, my advancement late, my traces faint as the smallest blade of grass. My shelves sag with books—dare I yet fall into the habit of idle embroidery? My bed is piled with few tablets of office, and I bear the shame of an unshaped bow or uncast sword. Once, I was tested afar in Ou and Min; for three years, I drifted like a drumstick on the waves. No administrative merit to my name, no words of praise to offer. Returning east with my jade intact, I sought grain in Chang’an; knocking at your gate, I presumptuously presented a letter like that of Guang Fan. Though the six hundred bushels of a *zhizhong* might still be climbed, the fifteen-foot heavens south of the city remain beyond even my dreams. Yet by your great power of uplift and the profound workings of creation, days pass and months come—no need for long military service; morning departure, evening arrival—truly a convenience for my family.

Not only have I been able to tend the graves of the orphaned on the plains where the wagtails nest, but I may also rest briefly in the village of chickens and pigs, allowing my lame steps to grind ink. In this stroke of fortune, how can I ever repay? Now, I humbly encounter your governance: the Eight Wastes open into domains, a single pillar holds up the sky. Xiao follows the compass, Cao follows the square—each in turn displays their merit to bring order to the age. The counsels of Fang, the decisiveness of Du—earnestly they cultivate governance to repel the barbarians. Office and rank are ever mindful of the heavy reins; men of talent are all gathered in the folds of your robe. Like unworked ore, I too am bathed in the kiln’s shaping.

How dare I not bear your great favor with reverence, upholding the teachings of my forebears? May I assist the mountain as it bears the carriage, and with my sash tied, ascend to the capital’s outskirts. What use is it to unfurl my steed’s potential? I listen for the whip on the locust-lined streets. How fortunate to stand among the hairpins and robes of the academy! I swear to dedicate my humble life in gratitude for your profound virtue.

On behalf of Zhao, Military Commissioner for Coastal Defense, I reverently note: your plans are deep and your governance expansive. In selecting a commander, who could surpass Yi of the Han? In military auspices, the Duke of Zhou presides over the east. Departing the jade steps, you set forth—heaven’s court rejoices in your union. I reflect that your breast holds ten thousand scrolls, your brush inverts the Three Rivers. From youth, you bore the expectations of the court; content with gradual advancement, you have endured the toils of command. When the court sought to rescue the paper currency, you embodied the noble image of "pulling the roots." At the pinnacle of the hundred officials, you navigated the two handles of power. Passing the Hall of Government Affairs, even the prime minister would listen with changed countenance; applying the standards of the *Spring and Autumn*, the historians would record your deeds with their brushes. Soon you would join the ranks of those who wear the hairpins of the law and carry the satchels of state, to settle the discussions of gold and silk with the Xiongnu.

In ancient times, at Mount Gou, the spring muster was held. Testing the faults of six or seven paces, the soldiers would clamor and lose formation. Yet bearing the double honor of a second or third appointment, you stood resolute as you took up your post. The vanguard was on alert, the willows of Xiliu changed color. You personally bestowed the azure axe of authority, leisurely playing chess in your villa’s separate garden. Like Han Yu entering the camp of Tingcou, the young warriors submitted; like Guo Ziyi succeeding Li Guangbi, the banners shone with renewed brilliance. Swiftly hearing your praises, I returned to join your counsel.

For me, attending court is a great fortune, though my grain transport duties are unworthy. Relying on the lingering radiance of the pivot of power, I hope to join the pure gatherings of the Moon Tower. Moreover, with the vermilion banner’s departure to the garrison, I rejoice in the added luster of the purple sash. My wandering heart is moved by parting, yet how dare I presume upon such grand courtesies? You spur your horse ahead of me—I lament my own stagnation like a single phase of hardship. Breaking willow branches to send you off, I can only pray for a reunion in glory. Our shared aspirations and heartfelt designs—how could they be exhausted?

On behalf of the Guardian of Yanzhou Prefecture, I reverently note: your mandate governs the domain, your banner planted at the auspicious hour. Your name is inscribed on the golden tally, its brilliance joining the eastern wall’s splendor; your carriage bears the vermilion banner, towering above the guest star’s station. Why did Shu Du come so late? The traces of Wen Zheng shine still.

I reflect that your learning rivals the archives of Ye, your bearing as refined as Kun’s jade. Solemn in thought, never lacking reverence, your demeanor is long practiced among the three thousand. Advancing in the Way, your magnanimity overflows—early on, you mastered the vital points of the twelve meridians. You share the reputation of the elder and younger brothers’ ocarina and flute, and possess the fragrance of the *Spring and Autumn*’s orchids and chrysanthemums. Fitting for the court, yet you serve in the provinces. Tracing the mast to the clear rapids, your halberds bristle along the upper reaches. Between fields and cottages, the people suffer under the white tax collectors; the granaries and treasuries stand nearly empty. Yet with your vision, you must change the board and place the pieces anew. Your skill surpasses others—you can make cakes without even showing your face. After just a few months of governance, the songs of the Five Breeches resound. Soon you will enter the ranks of the dukes and ministers, washing clean the armor and weapons.

I, your unworthy servant, can offer no worthy embellishment—my royal duties are but toil. The hair in the mirror has turned to stars, the tides at the river’s edge rise like houses. I was about to split the paper to congratulate you when suddenly your gracious letter arrived. Recalling your thousand cavalry passing through the capital, we shared but a single cup by the waterside. Observing the customs of the capital’s left, I long chanted poems among the mixed ranks. Borrowing the path of the pear-blossom shade, I soon felt the joy of Tao Yuanming’s return. My repayment is inadequate, my longing for your homeland deepens.

On behalf of Zhao, Supervising Censor of Anji Prefecture, I reverently note: you have been selected among the worthy, assigned to govern the capital’s outskirts. Joining the ranks of a dozen or so peers, you honorably wear the silver hare’s seal; ruling over the eight hundred states of the Ji clan, you purely occupy the palace of crystal waters. From your first descent into office, every household rejoiced.

I reflect that your conduct reaches high as the heavens, your capacity vast as the deep pool. Broad in learning and rich in knowledge, your staff shines like the blue flame of Taiyi; self-proclaimed in your elegance, you don the purple brocade of the banished immortal. Others know to rise straight to the clouds, but you proceed slowly, reining in your steed. Having soared to display your steed’s prowess, you now mount your horse to heed the cock’s crow. On the eastern bed of the forbidden palace, you have observed extraordinary scholars; in the western wing of the secretariat, why not gather the courtiers? Unwilling to linger in the shade of a single banner, you test your ability to summon the Six Guests. With ample leisure in official matters, the songs and odes resound near the heavens. Your retiring chambers are fragrant, awaiting the governance of Gong and Huang; in the hall of state, you will surely follow the footsteps of Fu and Yan.

I, your unworthy grain transporter, have long known your compassion. Recalling our unhurried conversations at the gate, I rejoice in your vigorous assumption of the governorship. Not relying on passing guests to adorn your kitchen, how could you again pursue the clerks’ door-knocking?
